citations.narrative:
In April 2024, baby otters were inadvertently left separated from their mom, resulting in one otter later being treated for
injuries as a result. During this inspection, the facility representative reported this otter was undergoing monitoring and
care, recovering from frostbite. The representative stated the local temperature dropped and became very cold the night
the otters remained separated from their mother. The next morning, one of the baby otters was found extremely
hypothermic, unable to move, and required immediate medical attention due to exposure. While the facility presentative
was unsure if the absence of the mother contributed to the one otter succumbing to this incident, additional facility records
denoted the event resulted from failure to reunite the babies with the mother. Another occurrence was mitigated three
days later, where the same baby otters remained separated again, until another colleague intervened and reintroduced
the mother to the enclosure with the babies prior to the facility closing.
Young animals unable to remain housed with their mother as needed can result in significant stress, illness, hypothermia,
or worse. The facility must ensure that animals are handled as expeditiously and carefully as possible in a manner that
does not cause trauma, overheating, excessive cooling, behavioral stress, physical harm, or unnecessary discomfort.
The facility corrected prior to this inspection.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the authorized person.
n

narrative:
2.131(b)(1)  Critical
   
Handling of animals. 
In April 2024, baby otters were inadvertently left separated from their mom, resulting in one otter later being treated for 
injuries as a result. During this inspection, the facility representative reported this otter was undergoing monitoring and 
care, recovering from frostbite. The representative stated the local temperature dropped and became very cold the night 
the otters remained separated from their mother. The next morning, one of the baby otters was found extremely 
hypothermic, unable to move, and required immediate medical attention due to exposure. While the facility presentative 
was unsure if the absence of the mother contributed to the one otter succumbing to this incident, additional facility records 
denoted the event resulted from failure to reunite the babies with the mother. Another occurrence was mitigated three 
days later, where the same baby otters remained separated again, until another colleague intervened and reintroduced 
the mother to the enclosure with the babies prior to the facility closing. 
Young animals unable to remain housed with their mother as needed can result in significant stress, illness, hypothermia, 
or worse. The facility must ensure that animals are handled as expeditiously and carefully as possible in a manner that 
does not cause trauma, overheating, excessive cooling, behavioral stress, physical harm, or unnecessary discomfort. 
 
The facility corrected prior to this inspection. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the authorized person. 
 
 n
